story:
Beer + Rocket = AWESOME.

I am Ben Jarvis, a dad, a husband, a regular guy from the east of England... with a somewhat extreme passion....

Since I was about 15 years old I have been obsessed with rockets. I have built over 300 of the things and made over 2000 launches in the last 25 years including being asked to launch rocket-powered toilets for TV shows and 40ft tall replica missiles for live PR events.

In the year 2000 my friends and I set a new European amateur rocket altitude record of over 34,000ft with a rocket we designed and built ourselves. Last year, that record was broken by a team from the Netherlands who sent a rocket to 70,000ft, over 21km in altitude.

I want to undertake a new record-breaking rocket project and get as many new people interested and involved in rocketry and space science as possible in the process.

I want our record back for the UK... my local brewery are going to help, and YOU can too.


Here's our current funding progress (updated daily) showing the key goals along the way!:


The Plan.

All of the greatest British inventions and schemes throughout history have been hatched in a pub or at least over a good beer. Rockets are no exception...

Ever since I was about 18 I had this idea of combining beer and rockets and making an attempt to launch a can of beer into space...or at least pretty close to it. You may ask why, I would reply... "Why not?", as the great land speed record hero Richard Noble once said... "For Britain and the hell of it". As I am older, wiser and fatter than I was in 2000 and about to hit the big 'four-o' this summer I figured it was now time to make it actually happen.

In all seriousness, it's about the ultimate democratisation of space flight... what brings people together like an idea shared over a few cold beers? The superficially silly idea of using something as esoteric as a space rocket to fly some beer out of the atmosphere is actually the best way to show that space is for all of us, if we can plan and execute a near-space rocket launch from our local pub, anyone can be part of the private space-race.

Our plan is to raise enough funding to build and then launch a new record-breaking rocket later this year, one capable of flying over 30km high, leaving almost all of the Earth's atmosphere behind and doing so with a small payload of beer on board.

This crowd-funding campaign is being run simultaneously with the brewing of a limited edition beer called 'Hop Rocket IPA' by the awesome team at Redwell Brewery in Norwich... the first beer brewed using hops which have been launched on a rocket!


You will be able to follow our progress on the rocket and during the launch itself on our facebook page here: https://www.facebook.com/hoprocketrecord/

Or on our website/blog here: http://www.hoprocketrecord.com


The Perks.

Whether you're a space-geek or a beer-geek, backing this project gets you some cool things... Just by donating a few pounds to the project you get your name immortalised on the project website as a supporter, for a little more you can get your name on the rocket itself, attend a rocket launch and build your own rocket with your family, get tickets to exclusive events... and access to the limited edition 'Hop Rocket IPA' beer being brewed especially for this project. Most of all... you get the satisfaction of knowing that you have helped achieve something pretty awesome and brought a record back to the UK.

IMPORTANT NOTE: We cannot offer alcohol as a perk for the project, as such what you will get instead is a ticket to attend an exclusive event for the project at which the Hop Rocket IPA beer will be available OR redeemable against an online purchase from Eebria.

It should also be noted that perks such as items flown on board the altitude record etc are dependent on A: the rocket being launched and B: the rocket being safely recovered. That is NOT guaranteed though of course we will do our VERY best to give everyone who backs the project something awesome to show our gratitude for their assistance whether the project is 100% successful or not.


The Rocket.

In September of 2000 myself and a small group of friends had a crazy adventure. We designed and built a rocket in just 10 weeks to try and set a new altitude record at over 50,000ft (the highest we had flown before this was just 15,000ft). We flew the rocket out in a wooden crate to San Francisco and then drove in a rented RV across the western US to the desolate Black Rock desert. We camped in that RV for four days and, with the help of some awesome characters and a few late nights powered by energy drinks shared from urine-sample bottles (rocket scientists use whatever is to hand to solve a problem) we launched our rocket and achieved a new record.

We set the altitude record at over 34,000ft (10km) with a rocket that defies the normal rules and takes a more 'extreme' approach to going high. The rocket, called 'Phobos EAV' was a boosted dart design. Conceived by NASA as a way to launch very small payloads cheaply to the very edge of the atmosphere a 'boosted dart' does exactly what it's name suggests...

It's all about drag and momentum. By using a very high-thrust rocket engine a boosted dart accelerates rapidly to an extreme velocity and then releases a thin, heavy 'dart' that sits atop the rocket motor, imparting most of it's kinetic energy into something with VERY low drag. This tiny dart then 'coasts' up through the atmosphere as it gently decelerates, eventually turning around and falling back to Earth (hopefully intact).

This design has the advantage of being able to send the dart section to a much higher altitude than a conventional rocket with the same amount of power could reach, but with the dissadvantage of A: being very small so not being able to carry much on it's journey, and B: everything on board the rocket needing to withstand massive acceleration at launch,

The Phobos EAV rocket was an imperfect design. The 'dart' stayed stuck on top of the rocket for several seconds after it should have broken free due to an error in the design of the attachment joint. We have learnt what we did wrong and are ready to try again... only this time, we are going for broke.

The new rocket has 35% more fuel than Phobos EAV and delivers over 3 times as much thrust. This new rocket will accelerate the dart to over 2000mph (nearly 3 times the speed of sound) in just over 1 second before releasing it. 

The smaller, more streamlined dart should then 'coast' for around a minute, reaching a peak altitude of over 100,000ft (30km) before beginning it's descent back to Earth, hopefully slowed down by a Kevlar 'para-streamer' which will be ejected from the dart using a small explosive charge.

We hope to carry not only electronic altimeters and GPS systems on the dart to record how high it has gone but also at least one miniature camera, built to withstand this extreme flight and hopefully bring us back video from the edge of space.


The Beer.

This whole project is being conducted with the help of Redwell Brewery who's rocket-themed branding on their craft beers caught my eye in a local shop and who offered to help promote the campaign. To kick off the project and provide a tangible reward to be enjoyed by those who help with the project, Redwell asked me to help them create a unique one-off beer. 

On Saturday 30th April this year a big red rocket lifted off from the East Anglian countryside carrying 5kg of hops in it's payload bay. This rocket wasn't ever intended to set any altitude records but was just designed to carry it's precious organic cargo to around half a mile in altitude on a fiery joy-ride.

The hops were recovered safely after the rocket parachuted back to the ground and were taken back to the brewery to begin the brewing process. As you read this, the awesome new 'Hop Rocket IPA' beer is being brewed and it should, we hope, be ready to try at the end of this campaign!

We hope to be able to give some of this small batch of unique beer to the backers of this campaign (at exclusive supporter events) and to toast the successful record attempt with it later this year. We will also be carrying a small sample of the beer with us on board the altitude record rocket... fulfilling that life-long 'beer-in-space' dream.


Why Help?

Launching rockets isn't cheap. It's cheaper than you might think, but it still costs money. We have turned to crowd-funding to raise the money for this project because we believe this is a genuinely cool project that not only brings a high-tech community science project to Norfolk and the glory of a record back to the UK but also inspires people to get involved in space science in a way that perhaps they never realised they could. Did you know, wherever you are in the UK there is probably an amateur rocketry club within a couple of hours of you that could help you build and launch your own rocket? Probably not, but it's true!

The funding we are asking for in this campaign will be spent on building the rocket itself (a task of small-scale but precision engineering), the electronic systems to go on board the dart (which will all need to be custom made and/or modified to withstand the flight), the fuel to power the rocket and, critically, the costs of getting the rocket and the small crew needed to launch it out to the only place remote enough to be able to safely launch something this extreme... the Black Rock desert in Nevada, site of Britain's past world land speed record glory and proven experimental rocket launching location.


Other ways to help

In addition to just donating to this campaign, it would be GREAT if you can share this campaign far and wide, encourage your friends and family to support us too. 
If you run (or know someone who runs) a relevant business in Norfolk or Suffolk and think you can help by donating goods or services to the project then that would be great as it allows us to allocate more of the funds raised to the other aspects of the project. Specific things we need help with include:

  • Miniature digital cameras/action cameras
  • Precision metalworking - Turning of steel parts
  • Precision metalworking - Fabrication/welding of sheet steel parts
  • Precision metalworking -  Turning of aluminium parts
  • Electronics engineering, specifically GPS and radio tracking systems
  • Electronics engineering - hardening/encapsulation of electronics for high-stress environments.
  • Logistics/travel for valuable/delicate goods and people to/from the western USA.

Risks and Challenges.

The first hurdle to overcome will be raising the funds needed to make the launch this year. With your help we can do that and make this happen. If we aren't able to raise the full funding during this campaign we hope to at least cover the construction costs of the rocket from this campaign, hopefully test-launch it and will look for other ways to raise additional funds to achieve the altitude record attempt. Every pound we raise will get us one small step closer to achieving the record-breaking goal.

Should we manage to achieve MORE funding than originally planned we aim to plough that money straight into improving the rocket. There are lots of things, given the extra budget, we can do to give the rocket a better chance of success and/or make it capable of going even higher.

Rocketry is, by it's very nature, a risky business. This rocket will be at the bleeding edge of what any amateurs have ever tried to achieve before and will involve some pretty extreme engineering and a good dose of good luck to get it to stay together, achieve it's goal, and return safely. There are always things that can go wrong with an experimental rocket but we are confident we have the best shot at achieving this.

If for any reason the record attempt is unsuccessful we would be aiming to learn from it and make another attempt as soon as possible.
story_txt:
Beer + Rocket = AWESOME. I am Ben Jarvis, a dad, a husband, a regular guy from the east of England... with a somewhat extreme passion....Since I was about 15 years old I have been obsessed with rockets. I have built over 300 of the things and made over 2000 launches in the last 25 years including being asked to launch rocket-powered toilets for TV shows and 40ft tall replica missiles for live PR events.In the year 2000 my friends and I set a new European amateur rocket altitude record of over 34,000ft with a rocket we designed and built ourselves. Last year, that record was broken by a team from the Netherlands who sent a rocket to 70,000ft, over 21km in altitude.I want to undertake a new record-breaking rocket project and get as many new people interested and involved in rocketry and space science as possible in the process.I want our record back for the UK... my local brewery are going to help, and YOU can too.Here's our current funding progress (updated daily) showing the key goals along the way!:The Plan.All of the greatest British inventions and schemes throughout history have been hatched in a pub or at least over a good beer. Rockets are no exception...Ever since I was about 18 I had this idea of combining beer and rockets and making an attempt to launch a can of beer into space...or at least pretty close to it. You may ask why, I would reply... "Why not?", as the great land speed record hero Richard Noble once said... "For Britain and the hell of it". As I am older, wiser and fatter than I was in 2000 and about to hit the big 'four-o' this summer I figured it was now time to make it actually happen.In all seriousness, it's about the ultimate democratisation of space flight... what brings people together like an idea shared over a few cold beers? The superficially silly idea of using something as esoteric as a space rocket to fly some beer out of the atmosphere is actually the best way to show that space is for all of us, if we can plan and execute a near-space rocket launch from our local pub, anyone can be part of the private space-race.Our plan is to raise enough funding to build and then launch a new record-breaking rocket later this year, one capable of flying over 30km high, leaving almost all of the Earth's atmosphere behind and doing so with a small payload of beer on board.This crowd-funding campaign is being run simultaneously with the brewing of a limited edition beer called 'Hop Rocket IPA' by the awesome team at Redwell Brewery in Norwich... the first beer brewed using hops which have been launched on a rocket!You will be able to follow our progress on the rocket and during the launch itself on our facebook page here: https://www.facebook.com/hoprocketrecord/Or on our website/blog here: http://www.hoprocketrecord.comThe Perks.Whether you're a space-geek or a beer-geek, backing this project gets you some cool things... Just by donating a few pounds to the project you get your name immortalised on the project website as a supporter, for a little more you can get your name on the rocket itself, attend a rocket launch and build your own rocket with your family, get tickets to exclusive events... and access to the limited edition 'Hop Rocket IPA' beer being brewed especially for this project. Most of all... you get the satisfaction of knowing that you have helped achieve something pretty awesome and brought a record back to the UK.IMPORTANT NOTE: We cannot offer alcohol as a perk for the project, as such what you will get instead is a ticket to attend an exclusive event for the project at which the Hop Rocket IPA beer will be available OR redeemable against an online purchase from Eebria.It should also be noted that perks such as items flown on board the altitude record etc are dependent on A: the rocket being launched and B: the rocket being safely recovered. That is NOT guaranteed though of course we will do our VERY best to give everyone who backs the project something awesome to show our gratitude for their assistance whether the project is 100% successful or not.The Rocket.In September of 2000 myself and a small group of friends had a crazy adventure. We designed and built a rocket in just 10 weeks to try and set a new altitude record at over 50,000ft (the highest we had flown before this was just 15,000ft). We flew the rocket out in a wooden crate to San Francisco and then drove in a rented RV across the western US to the desolate Black Rock desert. We camped in that RV for four days and, with the help of some awesome characters and a few late nights powered by energy drinks shared from urine-sample bottles (rocket scientists use whatever is to hand to solve a problem) we launched our rocket and achieved a new record.We set the altitude record at over 34,000ft (10km) with a rocket that defies the normal rules and takes a more 'extreme' approach to going high. The rocket, called 'Phobos EAV' was a boosted dart design. Conceived by NASA as a way to launch very small payloads cheaply to the very edge of the atmosphere a 'boosted dart' does exactly what it's name suggests...It's all about drag and momentum. By using a very high-thrust rocket engine a boosted dart accelerates rapidly to an extreme velocity and then releases a thin, heavy 'dart' that sits atop the rocket motor, imparting most of it's kinetic energy into something with VERY low drag. This tiny dart then 'coasts' up through the atmosphere as it gently decelerates, eventually turning around and falling back to Earth (hopefully intact).This design has the advantage of being able to send the dart section to a much higher altitude than a conventional rocket with the same amount of power could reach, but with the dissadvantage of A: being very small so not being able to carry much on it's journey, and B: everything on board the rocket needing to withstand massive acceleration at launch,The Phobos EAV rocket was an imperfect design. The 'dart' stayed stuck on top of the rocket for several seconds after it should have broken free due to an error in the design of the attachment joint. We have learnt what we did wrong and are ready to try again... only this time, we are going for broke.The new rocket has 35% more fuel than Phobos EAV and delivers over 3 times as much thrust. This new rocket will accelerate the dart to over 2000mph (nearly 3 times the speed of sound) in just over 1 second before releasing it. The smaller, more streamlined dart should then 'coast' for around a minute, reaching a peak altitude of over 100,000ft (30km) before beginning it's descent back to Earth, hopefully slowed down by a Kevlar 'para-streamer' which will be ejected from the dart using a small explosive charge.We hope to carry not only electronic altimeters and GPS systems on the dart to record how high it has gone but also at least one miniature camera, built to withstand this extreme flight and hopefully bring us back video from the edge of space.The Beer.This whole project is being conducted with the help of Redwell Brewery who's rocket-themed branding on their craft beers caught my eye in a local shop and who offered to help promote the campaign. To kick off the project and provide a tangible reward to be enjoyed by those who help with the project, Redwell asked me to help them create a unique one-off beer. On Saturday 30th April this year a big red rocket lifted off from the East Anglian countryside carrying 5kg of hops in it's payload bay. This rocket wasn't ever intended to set any altitude records but was just designed to carry it's precious organic cargo to around half a mile in altitude on a fiery joy-ride.The hops were recovered safely after the rocket parachuted back to the ground and were taken back to the brewery to begin the brewing process. As you read this, the awesome new 'Hop Rocket IPA' beer is being brewed and it should, we hope, be ready to try at the end of this campaign!We hope to be able to give some of this small batch of unique beer to the backers of this campaign (at exclusive supporter events) and to toast the successful record attempt with it later this year. We will also be carrying a small sample of the beer with us on board the altitude record rocket... fulfilling that life-long 'beer-in-space' dream.Why Help?
Launching rockets isn't cheap. It's cheaper than you might think, but it still costs money. We have turned to crowd-funding to raise the money for this project because we believe this is a genuinely cool project that not only brings a high-tech community science project to Norfolk and the glory of a record back to the UK but also inspires people to get involved in space science in a way that perhaps they never realised they could. Did you know, wherever you are in the UK there is probably an amateur rocketry club within a couple of hours of you that could help you build and launch your own rocket? Probably not, but it's true!
The funding we are asking for in this campaign will be spent on building the rocket itself (a task of small-scale but precision engineering), the electronic systems to go on board the dart (which will all need to be custom made and/or modified to withstand the flight), the fuel to power the rocket and, critically, the costs of getting the rocket and the small crew needed to launch it out to the only place remote enough to be able to safely launch something this extreme... the Black Rock desert in Nevada, site of Britain's past world land speed record glory and proven experimental rocket launching location.Other ways to helpIn addition to just donating to this campaign, it would be GREAT if you can share this campaign far and wide, encourage your friends and family to support us too. If you run (or know someone who runs) a relevant business in Norfolk or Suffolk and think you can help by donating goods or services to the project then that would be great as it allows us to allocate more of the funds raised to the other aspects of the project. Specific things we need help with include:

Miniature digital cameras/action cameras


Precision metalworking - Turning of steel parts


Precision metalworking - Fabrication/welding of sheet steel parts


Precision metalworking -  Turning of aluminium parts


Electronics engineering, specifically GPS and radio tracking systems


Electronics engineering - hardening/encapsulation of electronics for high-stress environments.

Logistics/travel for valuable/delicate goods and people to/from the western USA.
Risks and Challenges.The first hurdle to overcome will be raising the funds needed to make the launch this year. With your help we can do that and make this happen. If we aren't able to raise the full funding during this campaign we hope to at least cover the construction costs of the rocket from this campaign, hopefully test-launch it and will look for other ways to raise additional funds to achieve the altitude record attempt. Every pound we raise will get us one small step closer to achieving the record-breaking goal.Should we manage to achieve MORE funding than originally planned we aim to plough that money straight into improving the rocket. There are lots of things, given the extra budget, we can do to give the rocket a better chance of success and/or make it capable of going even higher.Rocketry is, by it's very nature, a risky business. This rocket will be at the bleeding edge of what any amateurs have ever tried to achieve before and will involve some pretty extreme engineering and a good dose of good luck to get it to stay together, achieve it's goal, and return safely. There are always things that can go wrong with an experimental rocket but we are confident we have the best shot at achieving this.If for any reason the record attempt is unsuccessful we would be aiming to learn from it and make another attempt as soon as possible.

story:
Short Summary

Cherron Covington, owner of CC’s Consulting & Services, LLC and No ordinary Kleaning.  Cherron moved to Florida from Georgia in June of 1998.  Born and raised in Washington, D.C., I was suppose to be a statistic; I’ve been a single mother, unemployed and homeless. In 1994 I started my construction final cleaning business.  I hire the homeless, veterans and ex-offenders; providing transportation and a meal to my employees.  In 2003 I employed as many as 45 individuals to work on three Better Jacksonville Projects.  Today I am an authorized OSHA trainer and consultant in environmental health, safety and services; I created a program and began teaching it in 2008. 

I provide transportation because when I was homeless the better jobs were far out and there was no public transportation that went out there.  

It gives me great joy to work with these individuals, as they are people who really want to change their lives for the better. I work with the employment specialists at shelters, who only send me those individuals who are really ready for a change for the better.   

 It will only take 1,000 people to donate $10 to help us get started here in Dallas, Texas.  We need to get work shirts, shoes, hard hats, our office and furnish it, it will pay for lunch while working,  We've bid two projects already, as Dallas is doing construction everywhere.  

  • TO SHARE IN WHAT WE ARE DOING WE HAVE THE FOLLOWING FOR YOU:
  • $50 pays for LUNCH for 5 people - Receive a Certificate of Thanks 
  • $120 pays for 3 shirts each for 5 people - Receive a Certificate & Shirt
  • $175 pays for work shoes for 5 people - Receive a Certificate, Shirt & Hard Hat
If we don't reach our $10,000 mark, the funds will still be helpful. They will pay for shirts, hard hats, work boots, and transportation for the new workers. 
The Impact
In 2006 the owner became an authorized OSHA trainer in OSHA General Industry, this allows her to train her employees and certify them in this certification.  This gives better opportunities when bidding and working contracts.  The owner also created  a training program that teaches environmental service to her employees and to the clients of shelters.  
This training gives homeless veterans and ex-offenders a better chance for employment in hospitals, hotels, etc.  This allows them to move into other fields outside of the cleaning industry.  
  • 2000-2005 obtained Projects that put over 45 homeless ex-offenders to work. 
  • 2008 - 2012 trained 150 individuals, 70% went to work, 10% went on to more schooling and 3% became business owners.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us  get the word out and make some noise about our campaign, with your social media pages.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • HELP US REACH OUR GOAL!!  THANK YOU

story:
Short Summary

The goal of our Swords into Plowshares campaign is to convert retired, de-commissioned military tanks into civilian earthmovers, bulldozers, excavators and agricultural tractors.  This is the first (ever) crowdfunding campaign for this type of industry. 

Our agenda addresses disarmament, sustainability, and economic and business development.  We are confident in our ability to make this agenda a reality.


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $300,000. This will enable us to:

 1.  Conduct an original design for a bulldozer/excavator kit mounted on refurbished tanks.

2.  Explore the availability of retired tanks in many countries around the world.

3.  Create a design for refurbished tanks, which will include the removal of the gun and turret, installation of a new driver cabin and auxiliariesand an increase in traction.  

4.  In the second phase, we plan to raise $2 million from various foundations, by crowdfunding, from corporate partners, venture capitalists, economic development authorities, and governments. We will test pilots with different tanks, develop project finance, develop rental networks for the bulldozers, and (most importantly) develop spare parts supply channels; we are currently discussing this agenda with manufacturers in Poland, Slovakia and Czech Republic that will supply spare parts on long term basis.

       


5.  As for perks, we (obviously) cannot provide a bulldozer to the donors…. We will, however, provide a few perks see a list.  If and when the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) makes the decision to allow equity crowd funding, and if the venture decides to conduct equity crowdfunding some donors will be informed so they may decide to take part in future equity offering. 


The Impact

The premise of this campaign is based on two main assumptions:

1.  The rate of obsolescence of tanks is fast. It is determined by military objectives (changes of armor, munitions, etc.,) rather than wear and tear.

2.  Tanks spend most of their lifetime in storage waiting for the next war.Except for a few hundreds hours of operation for training, (even) 30 years old tanks are in good mechanical condition.


We plan to start with the Soviet made “T55” tanks (the most produced tank in history) and then onto US retired tanks.  The “T55” can be found in more than 50 countries- most of which are developing countries.  The conversion of these tanks will be done using local machine shops and labor. This will provide a boost for economic development and provide inexpensive heavy machinery necessary for infrastructural development.  We, also, plan to help these developing countries obtain financing from world organizations that are involved with international aid.

         


Click Here to Enlarge Image

Our team and (potential) industrial partners in Poland and Slovakia used to manufacture the “T55” and retain the necessary technical expertise.


Risks & Challenges

There are always risks and challenges when entering into a phase of "me too" competition. We believe that we have the advantage of being the "first mover." Most likely, the new bulldozers will not be purchased, initially, so we plan to develop a worldwide rental operation.  This agenda is global in scope, so it will encounter some technical and execution- related challenges.  Once the pilots are proven to be effective, we will develop a management team of experienced executives with international expertise.

         


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the world by using the Indiegogo share tools.  

We are looking forward to hearing from each and every one of you and, of course, to your donation.  


FAQ

What is the main premise of your concept for Swords into Plowshares?

The attributes of military tanks lead to the following conclusions:

      1. The rate of obsolescence of tanks is fast, determined by military    objectives (changes of armor, munitions, etc.) rather than wear and tear.

      2. Tanks spend most of their lifetime in storage waiting for the next war.

      3. Save for a few hundred hours of operation during training, even 30-year-old tanks are in good mechanical condition.

     4. Military tanks are designed for speed and cruising in difficult terrains (mud, sand, hills, trenches, etc.)

    5. Military tanks are more powerful than large commercial bulldozers.


What kinds of modifications are required?

The turret and gun of the tank will be removed, and a new, modern driver cabin will be installed. The cabin should comply with OSHA regulations, so the driver will be protected in the event of a toppling.  A new hydraulic pump, a new kit of dozers, and shovel or blade is required.  Most likely, the tank will also require a new engine that complies with emission regulations.

Because tanks are designed for speed and bulldozers operate in lower speeds, it might be necessary to add a low gear that enables operation in lower speed, but higher RPM.  Also, the crawlers of the tank might be modified to increase traction.


Click Here to Enlarge Image

Can tanks be easily converted into bulldozers?

Yes. The engineering corps of every military uses their tanks as bulldozers for digging trenches, building bridges and other engineering functions.  The power of tank’s motor is comparable to that of a large commercial bulldozer.

Click Here to Enlarge Image

What is the business of your venture?

First, we will serve as intermediaries for those who have tanks and those who can provide the engineering for conversion.  Then, we will test pilots, provide a few designs and help with the development of project finance programs.  Finally, we will facilitate the rental operation of the new bulldozers.



Why Rental?  Why not sell (outright) the new bulldozers?

Initially buyers might be reluctant to purchase the new bulldozers, so rental seems more feasible.  It does not entail a financial risk for the customers.  After a few years of operation, (when credibility is established) the bulldozers might be sold.

The bulldozer industry is increasingly reliant upon the notion of bulldozer rental.  “Yard Club”, a Silicon Valley start-up, matches excess bulldozer capacity with those who want to rent.  Caterpillar Corporation and Kleiner Perkins are Yard’s investors.

Click Here to Enlarge Image

Can you transfer retired tanks across borders?

This is a tough question; some countries will refuse to transfer or export tanks that may be used again for military applications.  Therefore, we plan to first strip the tank in the country (where it is found) of its turret and gun.  We also propose that the engineering conversion is done at the country (where the tank is found) using local machine shops and labor.  For developing countries, this will provide economic development and access to inexpensive machinery required for infrastructure development.  These countries might also be eligible for financial assistance from world organizations.

What if military organizations request your services?

We are committed to provide and assist only civilian projects.  We will not take part in any military missions.  We ask participating parties to refrain from giving any military confidential information, since all the information we gather will be open to the public.


     


Why do you plan to start using retired Soviet-made T55 tanks?

This tank is extremely robust and is the most produced tank in history.  Tens of thousands of T55 tanks are retired in numerous countries.  We will start with a design for this tank, then explore other tanks, such as the US made M1 Abram tank, the German made Leopard and other Main Battle Tanks (MBT) that were manufactured by numerous other countries.  However, our kit for dozers, blade, shovel and excavator will fit any tank model: this enables mass manufacturing and cost reduction.

Do you know about cases where retired tanks have been successfully revived for active operation?

Yes. The Ukraine currently reboots their 20-30 old retired tanks into active duty, because of their current security issues.  See this video clip for reference:  


Can retired tanks be converted successfully into agricultural tractors?

Tanks converted into agricultural tractors are a very promising possibility, since (according to UN Food and Agricultural Organization:) “…more food will have to be produced over the next 50 years than has been produced during the past 10,000 years combined.”

Such agricultural expansion will require a massive investment in heavy machinery.  Our venture plans are to provide the hardware and use unutilized resources: retired military tanks and hardware that can be purchase at scrap value.

Our configuration of a tank used as a plowing tractor

Click Here to Enlarge Image

A telling, but amusing, example of tanks being used as tractors is the story of Vasily, Dmitry and Ivan Ivanov, three brothers from the rural settlement of Karatuzskoye in Krasnoyarsk Krai, Siberia.  They purchased T62 tanks from the military in the 1990s for the price of scrap metal. They claim that the tank is quicker, more fuel efficient, and easier to use on their 400 hectares of land than tractors.  You can read about these enterprising farmers and watch a video on their exploits at:

http://ftr.wot-news.com/2014/10/27/meanwhile-in-russia-8/

http://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/n0239-unique-way-to-plough-fields-using-military-tanks

Who might become your engineering partners?  What about spare parts?

There are a few engineering companies in East Europe that used to manufacture the T55 tanks: Poland, Slovakia, Czech Republic and the Ukraine.  Because bulldozers operate continuously (unlike tanks,) their rate of wear and tear is high. So, a steady and large supply of spare parts in required.  These engineering companies are excited about the business opportunity provided by our venture.  These companies will also help us with the pilot development.

Who are your competitors?  Can you protect your technologies?

This is a “brick and mortar” venture where patents are less relevant.  Our main advantage is being the “first mover.”  It will attract small competitors who will most likely not be major movers (i.e. Caterpillar Corporation or Komatsu.)  It is possible, however, that after demonstrating viability, a large company will buy our venture.  Alternatively, it is quite possible that a certain agency of a foreign government will purchase our venture or (at least) a portion of it.

Why not smelt the retired tank for its steel?

The prevailing prices of steel are on the order of ~$500 per ton.  A 40-ton tank will provide about $20,000 worth of steel.  This is not much relative to the work and cost that goes into building the tank.  The tank vehicle’s worth could be in the hundreds of thousand dollars.

What might be the cost of your new bulldozer?

We estimate that a converted tank into a bulldozer will cost ~$250,000.  The cost of a used 4 year old large D9 commercial bulldozer could be in the range of ~$750,000.

What are the benefits and the ultimate goals of your venture?

Our venture addresses the most wasteful sector of the world economy. We plan to cut in on this waste, beginning with the re-manufacturing of retired tanks, providing manufacturing jobs and providing the inexpensive heavy machinery required for infrastructure development in developing countries.

Based on the lessons learned, we plan to expand and use other retired military equipment and develop additional sustainable lines of business for applications worldwide.

       

        Espadas en Rejas de Arado

                  Promoviendo el Desarrollo Económico y el Desarme


Click Here to Enlarge Image


Interim Team

Moshe Alamaro, Campaign Leader has been working at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) as a grad student, research scientist and research affiliate for the past 20 years. He has a Mechanical Engineering Degree and M.S. in Atmospheric Sciences both from MIT.  He is a prolific inventor in a variety of fields, including energy and water systems. Moshe is also a certified auto mechanic and a retired naval officer. His work has received extensive media coverage in Nature, The New York Times, Harvard Business Review, Nature Medicine, The Economist, Le Mond, The Boston Globe,  Atlantic Magazine, New Scientist, Science News and numerous international media outlets. 

http://web.mit.edu/alamaro/www/


Diego Cornejo Barra

Jillian Butler 

Daniel Jacobs 

**The venture is currently recruiting  a team of engineers and executives to address the global expansion operation of Swords into Plowshares.**


Press

Interested in writing about us or using our copyright protected material? 

Please feel free to email us directly at swords.plowshares [at] gmail.com to schedule a phone call and/or conference.

 1.
 Conduct an original design for a bulldozer/excavator kit mounted on refurbished
tanks.
2.  Explore
the availability of retired tanks in many countries around the world.
3.  Create a
design for refurbished tanks, which will include the removal of the gun and
turret, installation of a new driver cabin and auxiliariesand an increase in traction.  
4.  In the
second phase, we plan to raise $2 million from various foundations, by crowdfunding,
from corporate partners, venture capitalists, economic development authorities,
and governments. We will test pilots with different tanks, develop project
finance, develop rental networks for the bulldozers, and (most importantly)
develop spare parts supply channels; we are currently discussing this
agenda with manufacturers in Poland, Slovakia and Czech Republic that will
supply spare parts on long term basis.       
5.  As for
perks, we (obviously) cannot provide a bulldozer to the donors…. We will,
however, provide a few perks see a list. 
If and when the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) makes the
decision to allow equity crowd funding, and if the venture decides to conduct
equity crowdfunding some donors will be informed so they may decide to take
part in future equity offering. 


The
Impact
The
premise of this campaign is based on two main assumptions:
1. 
The rate of
obsolescence of tanks is fast. It is determined by military objectives
(changes of armor, munitions, etc.,) rather than wear and tear.
2. 
Tanks spend
most of their lifetime in storage waiting for the next war.Except for
a few hundreds hours of operation for training, (even) 30 years old tanks are
in good mechanical condition.


We
plan to start with the Soviet made “T55” tanks (the most produced tank in
history) and then onto US retired tanks.  The “T55” can be found in more
than 50 countries- most of which are developing countries.  The conversion
of these tanks will be done using local machine shops and labor. This will
provide a boost for economic development and provide inexpensive heavy
machinery necessary for infrastructural development.  We, also, plan to
help these developing countries obtain financing from world organizations that
are involved with international aid.         
Click Here to Enlarge Image
Our
team and (potential) industrial partners in Poland and Slovakia used to
manufacture the “T55” and retain the necessary technical expertise.

Risks & Challenges
There
are always risks and challenges when entering into a phase of "me too" competition. We believe that we have the advantage of being
the "first mover." Most likely, the new bulldozers will not be
purchased, initially, so we plan to develop a worldwide rental operation.
 This agenda is global in scope, so it will encounter some technical and
execution- related challenges.  Once the pilots are proven to be effective,
we will develop a management team of experienced executives
with international expertise.         Other
Ways You Can Help
Please
spread the world by using the Indiegogo share tools.  
We
are looking forward to hearing from each and every one of you and, of course,
to your donation.  FAQ
What is the main premise of your concept for
Swords into Plowshares?
The attributes of military tanks
lead to the following conclusions:
      1. The rate of obsolescence of tanks is fast, determined
by military    objectives (changes of armor, munitions, etc.) rather than wear and
tear.
      2. Tanks spend most of their lifetime in storage waiting
for the next war.
      3. Save for a few hundred
hours of operation during training, even
30-year-old tanks are in good mechanical condition.
     4. Military tanks are designed for speed and cruising in
difficult terrains (mud, sand, hills, trenches, etc.)

    5. Military tanks are more powerful than large commercial
bulldozers.


What kinds of modifications are required?


The turret and gun of the tank will be removed, and a new,
modern driver cabin will be installed. The cabin should comply with OSHA
regulations, so the driver will be protected in the event of a toppling. 
A new hydraulic pump, a new kit of dozers, and shovel or blade is
required.  Most likely, the tank will also require a new engine that
complies with emission regulations.
Because tanks are designed for speed and bulldozers
operate in lower speeds, it might be necessary to add a low gear that enables
operation in lower speed, but higher RPM.  Also, the crawlers of the tank
might be modified to increase traction.


Click Here to Enlarge Image
Can tanks be easily converted into
bulldozers?
Yes. The engineering corps of every military uses their
tanks as bulldozers for digging trenches, building bridges and other engineering
functions.  The power of tank’s motor is comparable
to that of a large commercial bulldozer.
Click Here to Enlarge Image
What is the business of your venture?
First, we will serve as intermediaries for those who have
tanks and those who can provide the engineering for conversion.  Then, we will test pilots, provide a few
designs and help with the development of project finance programs.  Finally, we will facilitate the rental
operation of the new bulldozers.

Why Rental? 
Why not sell (outright) the new bulldozers?
Initially buyers might be reluctant to purchase the new
bulldozers, so rental seems more feasible.  It does not entail a financial risk for the customers.  After a few years of operation, (when credibility
is established) the bulldozers might be sold.The bulldozer industry is increasingly reliant upon the
notion of bulldozer rental.  “Yard Club”,
a Silicon Valley start-up, matches excess bulldozer capacity with those who
want to rent.  Caterpillar Corporation
and Kleiner Perkins are Yard’s investors.

Click Here to Enlarge Image
Can you transfer retired tanks across borders?
This is a tough question; some countries will refuse to
transfer or export tanks that may be used again for military applications.  Therefore, we plan to first strip the tank in
the country (where it is found) of its turret and gun.  We also propose that the engineering
conversion is done at the country (where the tank is found) using local machine
shops and labor.  For developing
countries, this will provide economic development and access to inexpensive
machinery required for infrastructure development.  These countries might also be eligible for
financial assistance from world organizations.

What if military organizations request your services?
We are committed to provide and assist only
civilian projects.  We will not take part
in any military missions.  We ask
participating parties to refrain from giving any military confidential
information, since all the information we gather will be open to the public.

      
Why do you plan to start using retired
Soviet-made T55 tanks?
This tank is extremely robust and is the most produced
tank in history.  Tens of thousands of T55
tanks are retired in numerous countries. 
We will start with a design for this tank, then explore other tanks, such
as the US made M1 Abram tank, the German made Leopard and other Main Battle
Tanks (MBT) that were manufactured by numerous other countries.  However, our kit for dozers, blade, shovel
and excavator will fit any tank model: this enables mass manufacturing and cost
reduction.
Do you know about cases where retired tanks
have been successfully revived for active operation? 
Yes. The Ukraine currently reboots their 20-30 old
retired tanks into active duty, because of their current security issues.  See this video clip for reference:  

Can retired tanks be converted successfully into
agricultural tractors?
Tanks converted into agricultural tractors are a very
promising possibility, since (according to UN Food and Agricultural
Organization:) “…more food will have to be produced over the next 50 years than
has been produced during the past 10,000 years combined.” 
Such agricultural expansion will require a massive
investment in heavy machinery.  Our venture
plans are to provide the hardware and use unutilized resources: retired
military tanks and hardware that can be purchase at scrap value.Our configuration of a tank used as a plowing tractorClick Here to Enlarge Image
A telling, but amusing, example of tanks being used as tractors
is the story of Vasily, Dmitry and Ivan Ivanov, three brothers from the rural
settlement of Karatuzskoye in Krasnoyarsk Krai, Siberia.  They purchased T62 tanks from the military in
the 1990s for the price of scrap metal. They claim that the tank is quicker,
more fuel efficient, and easier to use on their 400 hectares of land than
tractors.  You can read about these
enterprising farmers and watch a video on their exploits at:http://ftr.wot-news.com/2014/10/27/meanwhile-in-russia-8/
http://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/n0239-unique-way-to-plough-fields-using-military-tanks
Who might become your engineering partners?  What about spare parts?
There are a few engineering companies in East Europe that
used to manufacture the T55 tanks: Poland, Slovakia, Czech Republic and the
Ukraine.  Because bulldozers operate
continuously (unlike tanks,) their rate of wear and tear is high. So, a steady
and large supply of spare parts in required. 
These engineering companies are excited about the business opportunity
provided by our venture.  These companies
will also help us with the pilot development.
Who are your competitors?  Can you protect your technologies?
This is a “brick and mortar” venture where patents are
less relevant.  Our main advantage is
being the “first mover.”  It will attract
small competitors who will most likely not be major movers (i.e. Caterpillar
Corporation or Komatsu.)  It is possible,
however, that after demonstrating viability, a large company will buy our
venture.  Alternatively, it is quite
possible that a certain agency of a foreign government will purchase our
venture or (at least) a portion of it.

Why not smelt the retired tank for its steel?

The prevailing prices of steel are on the order of ~$500
per ton.  A 40-ton tank will provide about $20,000 worth of steel. 
This is not much relative to the work and cost that goes into building the
tank.  The tank vehicle’s worth could be in the hundreds of thousand
dollars.
What might be the cost of your new bulldozer?

We estimate that a converted tank into a bulldozer will
cost ~$250,000.  The cost of a used 4 year old large D9 commercial
bulldozer could be in the range of ~$750,000.
What are the benefits and the ultimate goals
of your venture?
Our venture addresses the most wasteful sector of the
world economy. We plan to cut in on this waste, beginning with the re-manufacturing
of retired tanks, providing manufacturing jobs and providing the inexpensive heavy
machinery required for infrastructure development in developing countries.
Based on the lessons learned, we plan to expand and use
other retired military equipment and develop additional sustainable lines of
business for applications worldwide.       
        Espadas en Rejas de Arado
                  Promoviendo el
Desarrollo Económico y el Desarme



Click Here to Enlarge Image


Interim Team

Moshe Alamaro, Campaign Leader has been working at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) as a grad student, research scientist and research affiliate for the past 20 years. He has a Mechanical Engineering Degree and M.S. in Atmospheric Sciences both from MIT.  He is a prolific inventor in a variety of fields, including energy and water systems. Moshe is also a certified auto mechanic and a retired naval officer. His work has received extensive media coverage in Nature, The New York Times, Harvard Business Review, Nature Medicine, The Economist, Le Mond, The Boston Globe,  Atlantic Magazine, New Scientist, Science News and numerous international media outlets. 
http://web.mit.edu/alamaro/www/


Diego Cornejo Barra

Jillian Butler 

Daniel Jacobs 



**The venture is currently recruiting  a team of engineers and executives to address the global expansion operation of Swords into Plowshares.**


Press
Interested in writing about us or using our copyright protected material? 
Please feel free to email us directly at swords.plowshares [at] gmail.com to schedule a phone call and/or conference.

story:
Do you wish there was a little more adventure and enthusiasm in the world?

Do you believe we should value passion over         paychecks and curiosity over comfort?

Then Turn Loose is for YOU.


Turn Loose is for all of us- it's about creating a community that supports these ideals and inspiring people to chase their dreams, get outside their comfort zones, and do more of what makes them happy.


Be a part of the movement. Tomorrow is ours.       Let's do this!


The goal of Turn Loose is to sell high-quality goods, using a portion of the profits to sponsor inspiring athletes and projects with cash support and share their stories with the world!


Turn Loose is something new.

Turn Loose is a community of renegades, explorers, and passionate visionaries.

Turn Loose is a brand on a mission– to champion the call to adventure and to support the stories, people, and communities that inspire others with money raised through the sale of our quality, unique goods.

Ambition and inspiration are the cornerstones of our mission. We believe in working hard to craft full and adventurous lives and passionately inspiring others to do the same.

The Story 

My name is Lauren Gregg and I am a professional mountain biker and the founder of Turn Loose. Discovering my passion in mountain biking was the best thing that ever happened to me and I'm now living out of my van and traveling the world riding my bike. Turn Loose is my way of paying it forward and inspiring people to chase their dreams, get outside of their comfort zones, and do more of what makes them happy.

Turn Loose will support and share stories that inspire change. It’s not about encouraging everyone to ditch their job and move into the mountains– it’s about sharing stories that can motivate even the smallest of changes, like going for a hike instead of working late, or finally taking that art class you’ve been dreaming about.

Obtaining cash support for projects has always been the number one struggle in my career. It’s relatively easy to get gear, but gear is no good if you can’t pay for gas or a plane ticket to where you need to go! Racing, competitions, and travel can be very difficult expenses for budding athletes. Turn Loose seeks to address these issues. People with the ideas and motivation for inspiring projects can come to Turn Loose for funding and Turn Loose will sponsor up-and-coming athletes with cash support creating stories to share with the community- a cycle of inspiration and support.


The Turn Loose Press   

We will share these stories online, and in the Turn Loose Press, a physical print that will arrive on community members’ doorsteps to be enjoyed over a cup of coffee before being made into a paper airplane. Other companies, collaborations, and organizations can also use this space to share relevant information, discounts, etc. with the Turn Loose community. An online version will be posted a week later.

ALL BACKERS WILL RECEIVE THE TURN LOOSE PRESS.

Does your company/organization/etc. want to be featured in the Turn Loose Press and on the website? Do you want to sponsor the launch?

Email INFO@TURN-LOOSE.COM for more information about getting your message out the Turn Loose community! 


By supporting the launch of Turn Loose, you're investing in dreams and becoming a part of the community here at the start. Here are the awesome perks available to support the launch: 

Faces and Places of Turn Loose 

Here are some of the rad people and projects already involved with Turn Loose. 

Lars was the first motivated young athlete to reach out to Turn Loose. He embodies everything we’re trying to promote- An incredibly well-rounded athlete, he already boasts a successful mountain bike race resume, was a member of the 3 time high-school state championship snowboarding team, and was captain of the varsity soccer team!

On top of these athletic achievements, it is Lars' volunteering and trail-building experience that really sets him apart. Lars volunteers his summers doing trail work with the Northwest Youth Corps, giving back to the mountain bike community and working alongside the forest service. He is currently completing their exclusive backcountry leadership program, the highest achievement a youth can receive with the NYC. This will give Lars a powerful voice for mountain bikers in the forest service. He’s the perfect Turn Loose ambassador and the type of young racer we are stoked to support. 

"Turn Loose means the ability to focus on the things that I am passionate about, the things that motivate and drive me forward towards my goals, so I can inspire others to do the same."

Clair Marie is a professional adventure sports athlete. She is one of the top female BASE jumpers in the world, a noted skydiver and a mountain bike racer. In addition to her professional sports she is also an avid rock climber, a model, and an inspiration of many. She started her adventure career at the age of  16 when she made her first BASE jump which gave her the title world's youngest female BASE jumper. Over the years she has dedicated herself to not only excel in her sports but to bring a certain femininity to all aspects of her sports which was severely lacking. She breaks all the stereotypes for action sports athlete and thrives on instigating change. 

Konrad, Trevor, and Tristan, Students, Rafters and Mountain Bikers 

“Together we are three college students and outdoor adventurers doing what we love and traveling Westward and exploring new terrain on two wheels and water.” 

This summer these students from the Appalachian mountains kayaked and mountain biked across the country filming their movie “Summer of Seeking the Perfect Line” giving insight into their lives and experiences as young adventurers. This is exactly the type of project that Turn Loose wants to support and we are excited to support these boys’ adventures in the future. 

“I’m a goofy light-hearted eleven-year-old with a great outlook on life and that likes to have fun, play with friends and ride bikes. I eat sleep and breathe mountain biking."

Carter is a regular at Whistler and is already shredding. A passionate up-and-coming rider, he races the NW Cups and has dreams of being a freeride athlete in the future. We can’t wait to support his riding and race career!

California Enduro Series

"California Enduro Series is excited to be partnering with Turn Loose. The focus on rider support and development Turn Loose is providing aligns with our mission in growing Enduro racing and athletes specifically in the next generation of riders. These athletes are the future of the sport and we look forward to seeing how they grow."

- Megan Gemelos, Series Director 

The California Enduro Series (CES) is a for-riders, by-riders operation, a 501c3 not-for-profit organization whose mission is to promote mountain bike enduro racing and riding by establishing and marketing a race series. CES provides a pathway for aspiring athletes to progress from local entry-level events to the world’s top level professional events.

LCRSP Skate Park

"We at California's Largest Skate Park are very excited to partner with the up-and-coming action sports brand Turn Loose. This will provide a great avenue for skaters and bikers to gain exposure and 'make it big' in their sport." 

- Justin R. Beck, City of San Jose Action Sports Specialist

Lake Cunningham Regional Skate Park (LCRSP) is the largest skate park in California. Featuring the world’s largest cradle, tallest vert wall, and largest full pipe, the LCRSP offers a wide variety of terrain for all skill levels to learn and enjoy. The LCRSP is open to skateboards, bicycles, scooters, and inline.  You'll see multiple disciplines mixing it up daily in their street course, multiple bowls, and vert area. The skate park is home to the veteran Pro skater Steve Caballero and hosts the annual World Cup of Skateboarding competition, the Tim Brauch Memorial Bowl Contest.



Other Ways You Can Help

We know some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Tell everyone you know about Turn Loose!

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign with all your friends!
